trial_identification.studytitle: Breast reconstruction for breast asymmetry by tissue engineering
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Breast reconstruction for breast asymmetry by tissue engineering

interventions.interventions: Breast reconstruction in an implanted acrylic spacer using the body's own ability to grow new tissue to fill the empty space provided by acrylic spacer over a perioid of 3 to 6 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Improved breast symmetry. New tissue growth will be measured using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Outcome will be measured 3 months post-operatively, and after that monthly from 3-6 months post-surgery until the spacer is filled with new tissue.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Improved breast symmetry and cosmetic result, monitored clinically by plastic surgeons

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Breast asymmetry, unlikely suitable for other reconstructive flap methods.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Bernard O'Brien Institute of Microsurgery (BOBIM) 42 Fitzroy Street Fitzroy, VIC 3065

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Bernard O'Brien Institute of Microsurgery (BOBIM) 42 Fitzroy Street Fitzroy, VIC 3065

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Study hypothesis: The human body has a natural capacity to regenerate and to grow new tissue to fill an empty space. This study applies a new method of breast reconstruction using the patients own regenerative capacity. This method provides an alternative to current breast reconstruction techniques and also an opportunity for patients who have no other option for reconstruction. In the operation an acrylic spacer, shaped according to the breast defect, will be placed under the skin of the chest wall to allow a piece of fat with a blood supply to grow over time (3-6 months) to fill the space created by the acrylic spacer. The small piece of fat with a blood supply will be sourced from well-known existing donor sites for breast reconstruction (chest or abdomen). Because the amount of tissue is small the expected donor site scars will be smaller compared with the usual reconstruction methods.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Human Research Ethics Committee-D St Vincent's Health Melbourne

contact.name: Prof Wayne Morrison
contact.address: St Vincents Hospital Melbourne 41 Victoria Pde Fitzroy, VIC 3065
